title: Heart pounding tear jerking masterpiece!
content: I began reading this book and almost put it aside as not very interesting, but I plodded on....by the last few chapters I was a finding it difficult to read through my tears and not wanting to put it down for a moment. post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 9, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This story of a Polish family during WWI and the present day daughter and extended family is a powerful one.  The children of immigrants often do not understand nor care to truly grasp the lives of their immigrant parents/grandparents.  This is especially so when those elders don't explain their circumstances or what it meant to live in a wartime country.  This book tells the story from two aspects, one of a young Polish woman, very much in love, who lives on a small farm with her family during the war and during the Nazi occupation of her country, and her granddaughter in present day Florida with her own family challenges with an autistic son.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2024

title: 4.5 stars!
content: Early on in the book, as I indicated previously, I was less than enthusiastic with the plot as the 96- year-old Polish grandmother has been hospitalized due to stroke.  Her granddaughter has arrived to her hospital bed and is met with the problem of lack of communication with her grandmother due to effects of the stroke. This is where her autistic  son becomes key to the plot.  Without spoiling the story I will leave it here only to say  this made the story very rich throughout.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The author obviously did much research into the occupation of Poland and destruction of gentle life in a farming community.  I have read, at length, many varying accounts of this era and must say this truly gives a sense of the fear and desperation of  the people whose lives are so changed as they are enslaved by the Nazis.

title: Oh. My. Goodness!
content: I'm a big WWII historical fiction reader - Pam Jenoff, Kate Quinn, etc. I count The Things We Cannot Say by Kelly Rimmer right up there among the best. Her research is impeccable, and the events are consistent with the time period. Most importantly, her characters simply sing. They develop throughout the book in a way that's realistic and represents both the strengths and frailties of human beings. By the end of the book, I had tears rolling down my face. This is one of those books that you don't want to end.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 5, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I never knew about Poland’s occupation by the Nazis except in a factual way. Now I can see it on an individual level affecting real families. I was reminded of intergenerational relationships and how people from the past affect our lives and our children’s lives…not just with hair and eye color but also with character traits like courage. I was reminded of love and how it’s the strongest, most powerful emotion on the planet. Families have their struggles, but many can be resolved with faith, love, and mercy.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
